meta.title: Umbral | Regime Transformation Monitor
meta.description: Independent analytical platform monitoring regime transformation dynamics in Venezuela.
meta.keywords: Venezuela, democracy, regime, political analysis, OSINT, democratization, transition, political prisoners, freedom

items.question: What is Umbral?
items.answer: Umbral is an independent analytical platform that monitors regime transformation dynamics in Venezuela. We use historical data, academic indices, and verified journalistic sources to inform about possible political change scenarios.

items.question: Where does the data come from?
items.answer: Our main sources include V-Dem (Varieties of Democracy), the ERT Dataset by Maerz et al., DEED (Democratic Episodes Event Dataset), human rights organizations like Foro Penal, and independent Venezuelan media such as Efecto Cocuyo, El Pitazo, and Runrunes.

items.question: Are the probabilities predictions?
items.answer: No. The probabilities presented are analytical estimates based on historical patterns of regime transitions globally. They do not constitute predictions or forecasts. Political events are inherently unpredictable.

items.question: How often is the information updated?
items.answer: The news feed is updated continuously. Political prisoner indicators are updated weekly based on human rights organization reports. Scenarios are reviewed monthly.

items.question: Is Umbral affiliated with any party or movement?
items.answer: No. Umbral is an independent data analysis platform. We do not promote any specific political agenda nor are we affiliated with parties, governments, or political organizations.

whatIs.title: What is Umbral?
whatIs.content: Umbral is an independent analytical platform designed to monitor and contextualize regime transformation dynamics in Venezuela. We combine rigorous academic data, historical indicators, and monitoring of verified journalistic sources to offer an informed view of possible political change scenarios.

scope.title: Scope and Purpose
scope.content: Our goal is to democratize access to quality analytical information about the Venezuelan political situation. We do not make predictions nor promote political agendas. We provide tools for citizens, journalists, and researchers to interpret signals and historical patterns.

methodology.title: Methodology
methodology.content: We use a multi-source approach combining academic democracy indices (V-Dem), historical regime episode datasets (ERT, DEED), independent media monitoring, and human rights organization data. Scenario probabilities are derived from analysis of global historical patterns of regime transitions.

acknowledgements.title: Acknowledgements
acknowledgements.content: This project builds on the work of researchers, journalists, and human rights defenders who rigorously document Venezuelan reality. We especially thank the V-Dem teams, the ERT Dataset authors, and Venezuelan civil society organizations.

footer.disclaimer: Umbral is an independent data analysis project. The information presented does not constitute political advice or predictions.

revertedLiberalization.name: Reverted Liberalization
revertedLiberalization.description: An episode of liberalization in an autocracy that failed to transition to democracy. While political space opened significantly after Gómez's death (the 'Post-Gómez opening') and during the Trienio Adeco, the process was abruptly reversed by the 1948 military coup, returning the country to closed autocracy.

regressedAutocracy.name: Regressed Autocracy
regressedAutocracy.description: A deepening of authoritarianism within an existing autocratic regime. Following the 1948 coup, the military junta rapidly dismantled the previous democratic institutions and restricted civil liberties, moving the regime further away from any potential democratization.

democraticTransition.name: Democratic Transition
democraticTransition.description: A successful episode of liberalization in an autocracy that resulted in a transition to democracy. Triggered by the fall of Pérez Jiménez and solidified by the Punto Fijo pact, this period established the competitive electoral institutions that defined the democratic era.

democraticBreakdown.name: Democratic Breakdown
democraticBreakdown.description: An episode of autocratization in a democracy that resulted in a transition to autocracy. Beginning with the election of Hugo Chávez and the 1999 constitutional changes, the regime experienced a gradual erosion of democratic norms ('preempted democratic transition' turned breakdown) that culminated in a closed authoritarian regime under Maduro.
